cards.back: A push or pull that can change an object's motion. Measured in Newtons (N). Example: Gravity pulling objects toward Earth.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The amount of matter in an object. Measured in kilograms (kg). Mass is constant regardless of location.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The force of gravity acting on an object's mass. Weight = mass × gravitational acceleration (W = mg).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The rate of change of velocity with time. Measured in meters per second squared (m/s²).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The product of an object's mass and velocity (p = mv). Momentum is conserved in closed systems.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The ability to do work. Types include kinetic (motion), potential (position), and thermal (heat) energy.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. Measured in Watts (W). Power = Work/Time.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: Force applied over a distance. Work = Force × Distance × cos(θ). Measured in Joules (J).
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.back: The ratio of useful work output to total energy input. Efficiency = (Useful Output/Total Input) × 100%.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics

cards.front: Define and explain: Conservation of Energy
cards.back: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
cards.subject: Physics - Mechanics
